exhibiting the well defined lines successively 
developed in its different parts is rather an 
ideal image than a true representation of 
nature.
63. <u>Water<\u>, introduced into a small spectral 
tube, was kept boiling till the last traces of air 
were expelled and then, before all water was 
evaporated, the tube [was] hermetically sealed. The 
direct discharge, if passing, scarcely rendered 
the tube luminous, but, with the interca 
lated jar, the peculiar red light of Oxygen 
appeared, exhibiting the characteristic 
lines H[alpha], H[beta], H[gamma], well defined. Where these 
lines became gradually expanded, the lines 
of the Oxygen-spectrum successively appeared 
with an increasing intensity, finally rising 
from the Hydrogen-spectrum, transformed 
into a continuous one. Here the heat 
of the discharge is increased by the increased 
density of the vapour of water, and reciprocally 
the evaporation is accelerated by the rising 
temperature of the discharge. The vapour 
of water is decomposed by the discharge, 
the ignited hydrogen resulting from the de 
composition exhibits a spectrum at a 
lower temperature than the resulting oxygen does. 
After the discharge ceases oxigen and 
hydrogen are recomposed again to 
water.
64. <u>Phosphorus<\u>, when treated like sulphur (35) 
exhibits a beautiful spectrum of the second order. 
<s>of [text?] bright lines, successively developed.<\s>
